{{Globalize|date=January 2013}} In [[Australia]], '''Trust money''' is held by a law firm on a client's behalf in a trust account with a [[Authorised_Deposit-Taking_Institution|bank]]. Trust money is held in connection with the provision of legal services and is highly regulated. A lawyer or law firm should not appropriate a client's trust money until certain regulations are met, which are different for each State in [[Australia]]. The Australian system regulating lawyers and their trust accounts has been labeled by the [[First Rudd Government|Rudd Government]] as an "unwieldy monster".<ref name="Rudd Comment">{{cite news|last=Berkovic|first=Nicola|title=Kevin Rudd to create new regulations for the legal profession|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/legal-affairs/rudd-vows-to-slay-monster/story-e6frg97x-1111118768981|newspaper=The Australian|date=6 February 2009}}</ref>
==Uses of trust money== Trust money is held to cover the practitioner’s [[Costs_(English_law)|fees and disbursements]] over a period of time and may be required to be topped up as a matter progresses.
==Regulations for handling trust money in Australia== The accounting of trust money is highly regulated and even though the money is controlled by the law practice the money still belongs to the client until such time as it is applied to an invoice or disbursement. The exact regulations in [[Australia]] are different for each State, in everything from cost disclosure to trust accounting, which lawyers say cause inefficiencies and cost clients millions of dollars every year.<ref name="Rudd Comment"/>
Prior to 1976 it was not uncommon for [[solicitors]] to pay their [[Costs_(English_law)|costs and disbursements]] from trust money without obtaining the clients instructions to do so. The profession at large now accepts that this practice is [[Crime|unlawful]] and that prior instructions must be obtained.<ref name="Issues"/>
After a 1976 [[New South Wales]] Supreme Court Decision<ref>Stewart v. Strevens[1976] 2 N.S.W.L.R. 321 (Helsham C.J in Eq)</ref> it appeared that withdrawals by a lawyer from a trust account could only be made in two situations: *the client has given clear instructions to that effect; or *the solicitor has a "particular lien", and obtained a court order entitling him or her to withdraw the money.<ref name="Issues"/>
In 1978 the [[law societies]] in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and [[South Australia]] advised their members that they should "issue a bill of costs to the client wherever costs are taken from the trust account and not take such costs until the client has had proper opportunity to object".<ref>See Law Society Bulletin (S.A.) (Nov.1978), Supplement and Law Society of S.A., ''Legal Practitioners Trust Accounts Manual'', p.38.</ref>
In 1984 the [[New South Wales]] Law Reform Commission published the "Fourth Report on the Legal Profession: Solicitors' Trust Accounts".<ref>{{cite web|title=Fourth Report on the Legal Profession: Solicitors' Trust Accounts |url=http://lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lrc.nsf/pages/R44OUT |publisher=Law Reform Commission NSW |date=1984 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407213714/http://lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lrc.nsf/pages/R44OUT |archivedate=April 7, 2011 }}</ref> Chapter five of that report was titled "Handling Trust Money: Issues Relating to Costs and Disbursements" and discussed many issues relating to trust accounts in NSW and around Australia.<ref name="Issues">{{cite web|title=Ch 5: Handling Trust Money: Issues Relating to Costs and Disbursements |url=http://lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lrc.nsf/pages/R44CHP5 |publisher=Law Reform Commission NSW |date=1984 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408115821/http://lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lrc.nsf/pages/R44CHP5 |archivedate=April 8, 2011 }}</ref>
The national legal profession model bill, which was supposed to eliminate the differences, took about ten years to develop and was finally signed off by the Standing Committee of Attorneys General, (SCAG), in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Standing Committee of Attorneys General|url=http://www.sclj.gov.au/sclj/standing_council_index.html|publisher=Standing Committee of Attorneys General|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref> All Australian States and Territories except South Australia have during 2004 to 2008 adopted the national legal profession model.<ref name="Law Council">{{cite web|title=The Model Legal Profession Bill Status of implementation|url=http://www1.lawcouncil.asn.au/lawcouncil/index.php/divisions/national-profession-project/the-model-legal-profession-bill|publisher=Law Council of Australia|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=Stateline>{{cite news|last=MacLennan|first=Leah|title=$4.5-million dollars discovered missing from the trust account of a local law firm|url=http://www.abc.net.au/stateline/sa/content/2006/s2302792.htm|newspaper=ABC Stateline|date=11 July 2008}}</ref>
==Withdrawing trust money for legal costs in Australia== {| class=wikitable |'''State''' ||'''NSW'''||'''Vic'''||'''Qld'''||'''WA'''||'''SA'''||'''Tas'''||'''ACT'''||'''NT''' |- |'''Year of current Legal Profession Act''' ||2004 ||2004 ||2007 ||2008 ||1981 ||2007 ||2006 ||2006 |- |'''Act based on National Model''' ||Yes ||Yes ||Yes ||Yes ||No ||Yes ||Yes ||Yes |- |'''Time to object after delivery of bill'''||7 days ||7 days ||7 days ||7 days ||? ||7 days ||7 days ||7 days |- |'''Time to apply for review''' ||60 days ||60 days ||60 days ||60 days ||? ||60 days ||60 days ||60 days |- |}
===New South Wales=== In [[New South Wales]] trust money is regulated by the ''Legal Profession Act 2004''<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Act 2004|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/consol_act/lpa2004179/|publisher=NSW Parliament|date=2004}}</ref> and the ''Legal Profession Regulation 2005''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Regulation 2005|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/consol_reg/lpr2005270/|publisher=NSW Parliament|date=2005}}</ref>
If you receive a bill from your solicitor and want to challenge a withdrawal, you have seven days to make your objection known. If you do not lodge an application for a Cost Assessment with the Supreme Court of NSW within sixty days after being given the bill, the solicitor will be able to withdraw the money from the trust account.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trust and controlled money accounts|url=http://www.lawsociety.com.au/community/thelawyerclientrelationship/Trustcontrolledmoneyaccounts/index.htm|publisher=Law Society of NSW|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Withdrawing trust money for legal costs-section 261 (1) (b) of the Act|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/consol_reg/lpr2005270/s88.html|publisher=NSW Parliament|date=2005}}</ref>
===Victoria=== In [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] trust money is regulated<ref>{{cite web|title=Trust Money|url=http://www.liv.asn.au/For-Lawyers/Regulation/Trust-Accounting/Trust-money|publisher=Law Institute of Victoria|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref> by the ''Legal Profession Act 2004''<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Act 2004 (No 99 of 2004)|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/vic/num_act/lpa200499o2004225/|publisher=Victoria Parliament|date=2004}}</ref> and the ''Legal Profession Regulations 2005''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Regulations 2005|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/vic/consol_reg/lpr2005288/|publisher=Victoria Parliament|date=2005}}</ref>
The law practice may withdraw the trust money if the practice has given the person a bill relating to the money and if the person has not objected to withdrawal of the money within seven days after being given the bill or the person has objected within seven days after being given the bill but has not applied for a review of the legal costs under the Act within sixty days after being given the bill.<ref>{{cite web|title=Withdrawing trust money for legal costs-law practices|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/vic/consol_reg/lpr2005288/s3.3.34.html|publisher=Victoria Parliament|date=2005}}</ref>
===Queensland=== In [[Queensland]] trust money is regulated<ref>{{cite web|title=Trust accounting FAQs|url=http://www.qls.com.au/For_the_profession/Practice_support/Resources/Trust_accounting_resources/Trust_accounting_FAQs|publisher=Qld Law Society|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=When can trust money be withdrawn for the payment of legal costs?|url=http://www.qls.com.au/For_the_profession/Practice_support/Resources/Trust_accounting_resources/Trust_accounting_FAQs#faq14|publisher=Qld Law Society|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref> by the ''Legal Profession Act 2007''<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Act 2007|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/qld/consol_act/lpa2007179/|publisher=Qld Parliament|date=2007}}</ref> and the ''Legal Profession Regulation 2007''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Regulation 2007|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/qld/consol_reg/lpr2007270/|publisher=Qld Parliament|date=2007}}</ref>
The law practice may withdraw the trust money if the practice has given the person a bill relating to the money and if the person has not objected to withdrawal of the money within seven days after being given the bill or the person has objected within seven days after being given the bill but has not applied for a review of the legal costs under the Act within sixty days after being given the bill.<ref>{{cite web|title=Withdrawing trust money for legal costs|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/qld/consol_reg/lpr2007270/s58.html|publisher=Qld Parliament|date=2007}}</ref>
===Western Australia=== In [[Western Australia]] trust money is regulated<ref>{{cite web|title=Trust Accounts|url=http://practitioner.lpbwa.org.au/Trust-Accounts|publisher=Legal Practice Board of WA|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Important Changes Legal Profession Act 2008|url=http://practitioner.lpbwa.org.au/Trust-Accounts/Important-Changes-Legal-Profession-Act-2008|publisher=Legal Practice Board of WA|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref> by the ''Legal Profession Act 2008''<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Act 2008|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/wa/consol_act/lpa2008179/|publisher=WA Parliament|date=2008}}</ref> and the ''Legal Profession Regulations 2009''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Regulations 2009|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/wa/consol_reg/lpr2009288/|publisher=WA Parliament|date=2009}}</ref>
The law practice may withdraw the trust money if the practice has given the person a bill relating to the money and if the person has not objected to withdrawal of the money within seven days after being given the bill or the person has objected within seven days after being given the bill but has not applied for a review of the legal costs under the Act within sixty days after being given the bill.<ref>{{cite web|title=Withdrawing trust money for legal costs, procedures etc. for (Act s. 225(1)(b))|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/wa/consol_reg/lpr2009288/s65.html|publisher=WA Parliament|date=2009}}</ref>
===South Australia=== In [[South Australia]] trust money is regulated<ref>{{cite web|title=Information for solicitors about costs|url=http://www.legalcomplaints.com.au/images/factsheets/factsheet9_information_for_solicitors_about_costs_december_2011.pdf|publisher=Legal Practitioners Conduct Board|date=December 2011}}</ref><ref name=Powers>{{cite web|title=Powers, objects and mission|url=http://www.lawsocietysa.asn.au/society/powers.asp|publisher=The Law Society of SA|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref> by the ''Legal Practitioners Act, 1981''<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Practitioners Act 1981|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/sa/consol_act/lpa1981207/|publisher=SA Parliament|date=1981}}</ref> and the ''Legal Practitioners Regulations 2009''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Practitioners Regulations 2009|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/sa/consol_reg/lpr2009316/|publisher=SA Parliament|date=2009}}</ref>
SA is yet to push the national legal profession model bill through parliament, because of a political deadlock over compensation for victims of trust account fraud.<ref name=Stateline/><ref name="Rudd Comment"/><ref name="Law Council"/>
A legal practitioner or law firm cannot appropriate money from a clients trust account in or towards satisfaction of a claim for legal costs unless a bill specifying the total amount of those costs, and describing the legal work to which the costs relate, has been delivered to the person liable to the costs either personally, or by post addressed to the person at the person's last known place of business or residence. The person liable to legal costs may at any time within six months after delivery of a bill of costs request the person claiming to be entitled to the costs to provide a statement showing in detail how the amount of the costs to which the bill relates is made up.<ref>{{cite web|title=Disposition of trust money|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/sa/consol_act/lpa1981207/s31.html|publisher=SA Parliament|date=1981}}</ref><ref name = SA41>{{cite web|title=Bill of costs to be delivered|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/sa/consol_act/lpa1981207/s41.html|publisher=SA Parliament|date=1981}}</ref>
In 2012 the Law Society of South Australia published a fact sheet on appropriating Trust Money for Payment of Fees.<ref name="3 days">{{cite web|title=Appropriating Trust Money for Payment of Fees|url=http://www.lawsocietysa.asn.au/PDF/Prof_Appropriating_Trust_Money.pdf|publisher=The Law Society of SA|date=9 October 2012}}</ref> The fact sheet explains that if a practitioner posts a bill for fees to a client, it is not legally considered to have been "delivered" in accordance with section 41(1)<ref name=SA41/> of the Act, until the minimum amount of time in which the bill would be delivered in the ordinary course of post has passed. The Law Society recommends that 3 business days be allowed to pass after posting the bill before appropriation of trust money towards that bill. Further, the Law Society states that if the client objects to the bill the trust money should remain in trust.<ref name="3 days"/>
===Tasmania=== In [[Tasmania]] trust money is regulated<ref>{{cite web|title=Trust Accounting|url=http://www.taslawsociety.asn.au/web/en/lawsociety/practice/account.html|publisher=Law Society of Tasmania|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref> by the ''Legal Profession Act 2007''<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Act 2007|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/tas/consol_act/lpa2007179/|publisher=Tasmania Parliament|date=2007}}</ref> and the ''Legal Profession Regulations 2007''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Regulations 2008|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/tas/consol_reg/lpr2008288/|publisher=Tasmania Parliament|date=2008}}</ref>
The law practice may withdraw trust money if the practice has given the person a bill, written request for payment or notice of proposed withdrawal relating to the money and the person has not objected to withdrawal of the money within seven days after being given the bill, request or notice the person has objected within seven days after being given the bill, request or notice but has not applied for a review of the legal costs under the Act within sixty days after being given the bill, request or notice.<ref>{{cite web|title=Withdrawing trust money for legal costs|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/tas/consol_reg/lpr2008288/s53.html|publisher=Tasmania Parliament|date=2008}}</ref>
===Australian Capital Territory=== In the [[Australian Capital Territory]] trust money is regulated by the ''Legal Profession Act 2006''<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Act 2006|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/act/consol_act/lpa2006179/|publisher=ACT Parliament|date=2006}}</ref> and the ''Legal Profession Regulations 2006''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Regulation 2007|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/act/consol_reg/lpr2007270/|publisher=ACT Parliament|date=2007}}</ref>
The law practice may withdraw the trust money if the practice has given the person a bill relating to the money and if the person has not objected to withdrawal of the money not later than seven days after being given the bill or the person has objected not later than seven days after being given the bill but has not applied for a review of the legal costs under the Act not later than sixty days after being given the bill.<ref>{{cite web|title=Withdrawing trust money for legal costs—Act, s 229 (1) (b)|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/act/consol_reg/lpr2007270/s62.html|publisher=ACT Parliament|date=2007}}</ref>
===Northern Territory=== In the [[Northern Territory]] trust money is regulated<ref>{{cite web|title=Trust Account Information Sheets|url=http://lawsocietynt.asn.au/for-the-profession/trust-accounts/information-sheets|publisher=Law Society Northern Territory|date=18 January 2013}}</ref> by the ''Legal Profession Act''<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Act|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nt/consol_act/lpa179/|publisher=NT Parliament|date=2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Act 2006|url=http://www.lexisnexis.com.au/lexisweb/legislation/nt/nt_act_2006-38/legal-profession-act-2006|publisher=Lexis Nexis|date=2006}}</ref> and the ''Legal Profession Regulations''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Profession Regulations|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nt/consol_reg/lpr288/|publisher=NT Parliament|date=2006}}</ref>
The law practice may withdraw the trust money if the practice has given the person a bill relating to the money and if the person has not objected to withdrawal of the money within seven days after being given the bill or the person has objected within seven days after being given the bill but has not applied for a review of the legal costs under the Act within sixty days after being given the bill.<ref>{{cite web|title=Withdrawing trust money for legal costs|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nt/consol_reg/lpr288/s68.html|publisher=NT Parliament|date=2006}}</ref>
==Disputes over trust money== In Australia if a dispute arises over the accounting or application of the trust money the client should notify the appropriate Law Society.
One high-profile South Australian case was with Brenton Willoughby, a law clerk at Magarey Farlam Lawyers, and involved $4.5 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=James|first=Colin|title=Law clerk in $4.5m fraud|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/law-clerk-in-45m-fraud/story-e6frea83-1111112859407|newspaper=The Advertiser|date=19 January 2007}}</ref>
Another high-profile South Australian case was the "Stashed cash affair" involving the Crown Solicitors Trust Account.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dowdell|first=Andrew|title='Stashed cash' woman sues for $2m|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/stashed-cash-woman-sues-for-2m/story-e6freo8c-1111116040491|newspaper=Adelaide Now|date=11 April 2008}}</ref> The South Australian Attorney-General at the time, [[Michael Atkinson]], likened his Supreme Court cross-examination over the "stashed cash affair" to being "tortured with a comfy cushion".<ref>{{cite news|last=Wills|first=Daniel|title=Michael Atkinson 'unaware' of stashed cash, he tells Supreme Court|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/atkinson-in-court-over-stashed-cash-affair/story-e6frea6u-1225887934819|newspaper=Adelaide Now|date=5 July 2010}}</ref>
In 2009 a Perth lawyer was charged with stealing $11,000 from a trust account.<ref>{{cite news|first=Staff|title=Lawyer accused of stealing $11,000 from trust fund|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/lawyer-accused-of-stealing-11000-from-trust-fund/story-e6frea6u-1225792798171|newspaper=Perth Now|date=29 October 2009}}</ref>
In South Australia in 2010, in Australia's most expensive divorce, claims of overcharging and discrepancies handling trust money were made.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fewster|first=Sean|title=Australia's most expensive divorce: Woman fights $10.5m legal bill|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/money/money-matters/australias-most-expensive-divorce-woman-fights-105m-legal-bill/story-fn3hwldr-1225888724112|newspaper=The Advertiser|date=6 July 2010}}</ref>
A high-profile case of mishandling trust money was in Queensland, where a Logan councilor [[Hajnal_Ban|Hajnal Black]] was found to have mishandled trust money for a dementia patient. Ms Black was found guilty of four charges relating to pecuniary interests and fined $5,000.<ref>{{cite news|last=Baskin|first=Brooke|title=Hajnal Black on move to Brisbane Court of Appeal as warrant for her arrest remains active|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/hajnal-black-diagnosed-with-laryngitis-as-warrant-for-her-arrest-remains-active/story-e6frea6u-1226304034309|newspaper=The Courier-Mail|date=19 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Baskin|first=Brooke|title=Hajnal Black fined $5000 after being found guilty of four charges relating to pecuniary interests|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/hajnal-black-found-guilty/story-e6frea6u-1226311101288|newspaper=The Courier-Mail|date=27 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Oberhardt|first=Mark|title=Appeal judges reveal reasons behind dismissal of Hajnal Black's case last month|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/appeal-judges-reveal-reasons-behind-dismissal-of-hajnal-blacks-case-last-month/story-e6frea6u-1226319775514|newspaper=The Courier-Mail|date=5 April 2012}}</ref>
A New South Wales Criminal lawyer, Brett Galloway, was found guilty in 2012 for charges relating to his trust account handling.<ref>{{cite news|last=Carson|first=Vanda|title=Criminal lawyer found guilty|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/national/criminal-lawyer-found-guilty/story-fndo1sdf-1226432797802|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=23 July 2012}}</ref>
Another high-profile case was that of a Perth lawyer, Lloyd Rayney, who was charged with murder of his [[Death_of_Corryn_Rayney|wife]], but found not guilty of the murder in late 2012. During Rayney's murder investigation, trust money anomalies in his 2 daughter's trust accounts were found. They had received payments of more than $200,000 from one of Mr Rayney's biggest clients, [[Gina Rinehart]]'s Hancock Prospecting.<ref>{{cite news|last=Caccetta|first=Wendy|title='Anomalies' in Rayney daughters' trust accounts, court told|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/national/how-lloyd-rayney-wanted-to-join-was-legal-elite/story-fndo1nvd-1226490741270|newspaper=Perth Now|date=9 October 2012}}</ref>
==Legal Practitioners' Guarantee Fund== In [[South Australia]] in the 1960s a Guarantee Fund was set up from a percentage of the interest made on clients' money while in legal trust accounts.<ref>{{cite news|last=Merritt|first=Chris|title=Drop in trust fund deposits to hit services|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/legal-affairs/drop-in-trust-fund-deposits-to-hit-services/story-e6frg97x-1225766917271|newspaper=The Australian|date=28 August 2009}}</ref> The Guarantee Fund is administered by the [[Law Society]]<ref name=Powers/> and is used to fund consumer protection services such as the Legal Practitioners Conduct Board and to make hardship payments when people have lost money from legal trust accounts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Guarantee fund|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/sa/consol_act/lpa1981207/s57.html|publisher=SA Parliament|date=1981}}</ref><ref name=Stateline/><ref>{{cite web|title=Legal Practitioner's Act funding|url=http://www.lsc.sa.gov.au/cb_pages/funding.php|publisher=Legal Services Commission of SA|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref>
==Solicitors Guarantee Fund, Victoria==
Until the mid-1990s there was a Solicitors Guarantee Fund in Victoria (SGF). From the mid-1990s, after the relevant Victorian legislation was changed, a new Solicitors Fidelity Fund (SFF) came into being in place of the SGF. The legal interpretation of the two words effected by the change from SGF to SFF is significant. "Guarantee" and "Fidelity" do not mean the same thing. By implication the new fidelity fund did not provide a guarantee, the financial considerations are different with on the one hand liability of the fund vis-a-vis fidelity being limited to a finite amount, and on the other hand, in earlier times - the "Guarantee era" - liability of the fund being unlimited.
During the early to mid-1990s the amount of clients' money being lost at the hands of some Victorian solicitors became so large that the Solicitors Guarantee Fund began running year in year out in deficit, since it did not have sufficient income to meet the gross admitted claims against the fund. One of several major contributors to the ongoing deficit situation was Dudley Tregent & Co, which involved defalcations of between $10 million and $14 million of clients' funds. The core amount of $10 million to $14 million was topped up by a further $3 million or so in interest payable on claims because of the time it took to settle admitted claims, a period of 6 years from 1992 to 1998, while interest was accruing on the pending payouts at a statutory rate of 5% per annum.
Two other significant cases of solicitors losing clients' funds took place in the 1990s.
One of these was the small legal firm Tietyens' practice on the border with NSW. Tietyens ran a contributory mortgage scheme backed by about 1,100 investors that furnished an investment of about $42 million in the Tally Ho Retirement Village in Burwood East in Melbourne.
A further Melbourne case was the murder of Max Green in Phnom Penh. Max Green was a partner in the law firm Aroni Colman. In the Max Green case the amount lost was estimated at $38 million, ostensibly the $38 million was for the purchase of plant and equipment to be then leased to Transurban. Transurban denied any knowledge of this leasing arrangement. Some of the clients of Mr Green who lost their money in this case were other solicitors.
In general, the fidelity funds or guarantee funds do not admit claims involving criminal conduct or dishonest conduct on the part of the lawyers. Fidelity funds ironically are not designed to rectify infidelities, rather they cater for losses arising from honest mistakes by lawyers and/or their lack of investment acumen.
==Positive dormant balance at end of matter== If there remains a positive dormant balance in a clients trust account at the end of a matter, the client is entitled to the return of that trust money as soon as practicable. In 2012 South Australian Law Society director of Professional Standards, Ros Burke, advised practitioners that they could use the ''Unclaimed Money Act'' to clear the balance. By charging a fee to try to locate the client that the trust money belongs to, as long as the fee is generated in accordance with the appropriate ''Legal Practitioners Act'', the practitioner can appropriate that sum out of the dormant trust money.<ref>{{cite web|last=Burke|first=Ros|title=Dormant balances in the trust account|url=http://www.lawsocietysa.asn.au/PDF/Prof_Dormant_Balances.pdf|publisher=The Law Society of SA|date=21 August 2012}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person |birth_name = Vladimir Victorovich Anisimoff <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: | image = Portrait of Vladimir Anisimoff by Lyudmila Minina 2000.jpg --> | caption = Portrait by Lyudmila Minina (2000) | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1950|03|14}} | birth_place = [[Leningrad]], [[USSR]] | occupation = Composer and physicist | nationality = Russian | relatives = [[Vasily Anisimoff]], [[:ru:Афанасьев, Пётр Онисимович|Pyotr Afanasiev]] | spouse = Nina Ivanova (Neyolova) | children = Anna, Dmitry | alma_mater = [[Saint Petersburg State Electrotechnical University]], [[Seminar of Amateur composers]] | signature = }}
'''Vladìmir Anísimoff''' (born 14 March 1950<ref>{{cite web|title=ВЛАДИМИР АНИСИМОВ (РОД. 1950)|url=http://classic-online.ru/ru/composer/Anisimoff/17907}}</ref> in [[Leningrad]], [[USSR]]) is a Russian composer, scientist-[[physicist]], philosopher-agnostic, writer, and philanthropist. He is [[grandnephew]] of revolutionary-[[Mensheviks|menshevik]] [[Vasily Anisimoff]] and [[grandnephew]] of the famous Soviet pedagogue [[:ru:Афанасьев, Пётр Онисимович|Pyotr Afanasiev]], who created the most popular in the young Soviet Russia ABC book in Russian language "Read, write, count" (24 editions) and the Russian language Textbook for primary school. Vladimir Anísimoff is famous as a scientist in the field of magnetic resonance.<ref>Владимир Викторович Анисимов "Исследование взаимодействий ядерных спинов с решеткой в некубических кристаллах методами магнитного и акустического резонансов" Автореферат на соискание ученой степени кандидата физико-математических наук. 1979. [[National Library of Russia|Российская Национальная Библиотека]], [[St. Petersburg|Санкт-Петербург]]</ref> He developed method for the study of hidden internal surfaces,<ref name="multiple">Владимир Викторович Анисимов "ЯМР как метод исследования энергетической неоднородности скрытых поверхностей" Автореферат на соискание ученой степени доктора физико-математических наук. 1989. [[Semenov Institute of Chemical Physics|ИХФ АН СССР]], [[Moscow|Москва]]</ref> also he worked in the field of [[magnetic resonance imaging]],in particular, in the study of membranes.<ref>В.В.Анисимов, В.Ф.Сафронов, Л.А.Колонтаевская "Линии ЯМР 1Н воды в микроэмульсиях", '''Доклады Академии Наук СССР''', том 266, № 2, стр. 374, 1982. УДК 541.183:541.182: Физическая химия, Представлено академиком [[Nikolay Emanuel|Н.М.Эмануэлем]] 22 II 1982</ref> Also he known as the author of rare duration and depth of the content of the Symphony "FrognerPark".<ref>{{cite web|title=Владимир Анисимов Симфония N 2 "Фрогнер-Парк"|url=http://arustra.narod.ru/music.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Vladimir Anisimoff Symphony no.2 "FROGNERPARK"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w7jjntDze4M}}</ref> This Symphony is similar to sculptural FrognerPark of [[Gustav Vigeland]] in Oslo and reflects a full range of feelings and emotions of a person during his life. "Unicum Organum" is his fundamental philosophical work in the understanding of human life as a continuous process of information processing by chemical processors of brain.
== Biography ==
=== Early years === Vladimir Anisimoff was born on 14 March 1950 in [[Leningrad]], [[USSR]] in the family of construction engineer Victor Anisimoff, the nephew of the famous Russian revolutionary [[Vasily Anisimoff]]. He received an excellent private and public education in the Soviet period in Russia. : Vladimir Anisimoff since childhood fond of music, and especially music composition, but on the advice of his parents, he first received higher education in engineering. : Simultaneously, he studied choral conducting at the [[:ru:Музыкальная школа имени Н. А. Римского-Корсакова|Rimsky-Korsakov Music College for adults]] in [[Saint-Petersburg]].
=== Scientific activity === Vladimir Anisimoff started his research in the field of magnetic resonance in the early 1970s under the leadership of Professors Alexander Belonogov and Dmitry Dianov in [[Saint Petersburg State Electrotechnical University]]. In 1980 he received the degree of philosophy doctor ([[Saint Petersburg State Electrotechnical University]] and [[Saint Petersburg State University]], opponent was professor of [[Saint Petersburg State University]] Vladimir Shutilov) and continued his studies in cooperation with academician [[Nikolay Emanuel]]. After the sudden death [[Nikolay Emanuel|Emanuel]] in 1984 Vladimir Anisimoff continued his research under the guidance of academician [[:ru:Бучаченко, Анатолий Леонидович|Anatoly Buchachenko]]. In 1989 [[:ru:Бучаченко, Анатолий Леонидович|Anatoly Buchachenko]] presented Vladimir Anisimoff to the protection of the second (as it is accepted in Russia) doctoral thesis.<ref name="multiple" /> : For 20 years Vladimir Anisimoff has published about 50 scientific works. [[File:Vladimir Anisimoff composer & physicist 2009.jpg|thumb|left|Vladimir Anisimoff is composer & physicist]]
==== main scientific works ==== * V.L. Komashnja, V.V. Anisimoff. "Quadrupole & Hexadecapole 27Al nuclei transitioins studies in leucosapphire", Journal of Molecular Structure. Amsterdam, 83(1982), p. 391 * V.V. Anisimoff, presented by academician [[Nikolay Emanuel|N. Emanuel]] "Lines of magnetic resonance of protons of water in micro emulsions", Reports of Academy of Sciences. Moscow, 266, N 2(1982), p. 374 * V.V. Anisimoff, "Magnetic resonance methods in research of processes on surfaces" (great overview of the present status of these studies), Surface. Moscow, N 9 (1984), p. 5
=== Business and philanthropy === During [[perestroika]] (1986–2000), Vladimir Anisimoff had to get a new education – broker on the currency exchange. In 1993 Vladimir Anisimoff organized a joint stock company "New Company of Investors" '''NCI corp.'''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://infored.ru/company/583594 | title = Joint stock company '''NCI corp.'''(ОАО '''НКИ''')}}</ref> It served production garages for population, and a full range of printing services. : At the same time, as the President of the '''NCI corp.''', Vladimir Anisimoff organized together with his friend the composer Alexander Sledin<ref>[http://bogemnyipeterburg.net/vocabulare/alfavit/persons/s/sledinaleksandr.htm Magazine "Bohemian Petersburg", "Alexander Sledin"]</ref> regular concerts on Ostrovsky square in [[St. Petersburg]] in Hall of [[:ru:Санкт-Петербургская государственная Театральная библиотека|St. Petersburg state theatre library]], which played music of modern composers of [[St. Petersburg|Petersburg]]. The concerts were carried out regularly over four seasons from 1993 to 1997.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://sptl.spb.ru/?lang=en | title = Saint-Petersburg state theatre library}}</ref> : Since 2005 Vladimir Anisimoff financially assisted the organization of many concerts of famous [[St. Petersburg]] teams and in Russia, and abroad. In particular, some time he supported the [[:ru:Роговой оркестр|Horn Orchestra of Russia]].<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.horns.ru | title = Horn Orchestra of Russia}}</ref> : In the period from 2001 to 2003 the '''NCI corp.''' has undergone [[Corporate raid|capture raid]] on the part of power structures of [[St. Petersburg]]. According opinion of composer Alexander Sledin<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.spb-composers.ru/composers/126-sledin-/394-sledinbio | title = Alexander Sledin}}</ref> "It came under the control of people who had no connection either philanthropy or to the understanding of human relations between people". : From 2010 Vladimir Anisimoff retired and became the only composer and writer. : In 2009 Vladimir Anisimoff together with his son Dmitry Anisimov founded a new type of Philharmonic – the [[Virtual International Philharmonic]].
=== Music === Vladimir Anisimoff really began to study composition at the [[Seminar of Amateur composers]] in class of [[Johann Admoni]] in 1971, and completed his study with professor [[Joseph Pustylnik]] in 1980.
==== main musical works ==== * Symphony no.1 "Analysis and Synthesis" op.14, 1975, final edition – 2011 * Symphony no.2 "FROGNERPARK" op.without number, 1991 * Symphony no.3 "SINFONIA PICCOLA" op.33, 2004<ref>{{citation | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0mXAU9f-Mxc | title = Vladimir Anisimoff SINFONIA PICCOLA, premiere in "Kareliasali", Imatra, Suomi-Finland, 2009}}</ref> * Chamber music, in particular, – "Traffic sing", poems by [[Konstantin Vanshenkin]] (op.2,1972), "Andante cantabile" for violin & piano(op.12, 1975), "Sonata for the piano" (op.6,1973), "Chaconne" for string quartet (op.11, 1974), "Space ways" for oboe, fagotto & computer (2005) and many others. * Musical "Only, Only Ready Cash" (in Russian "Чистоган")(op. 29, 2003–2010, the musical was written about the period of [[perestroika]], it was censored and excluded from the plan of the theater's performances)
==== discography ==== * Альбом "Владимир Анисимов, Камерная музыка", Петербургская студия грамзаписи, Санкт-Петербург, 1999 * Album "Sounds are stars...",Symphonic and chamber music, [[:ru:Роговой оркестр|the Horn Orchestra of Russia]], conductor [[Serge Polyanichko]], ASE Studio, (exclusive release, limited edition), [[St. Petersburg]], 2012.
=== Philosophy === After Vladimir Anisimoff has become known in their field scholar, in 2005 he decided to summarize their knowledge in philosophical work "UNICUM ORGANUM"<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.anisimovdmitry.com/Documents/Father/UnicumOrganum_VladimirAnisimoff.pdf|title = Владимир Анисимов "UNICUM ORGANUM"}}</ref> : He has consistently promoted the ideas of [[Immanuel Kant]] about the unknowable essence of the matter.
=== Fiction === Recently since 2004 Vladimir Anisimoff was fond of writing funny stories. He finds himself in these simple stories about everything he sees around him.
==== Published ==== * Vladimir Anisimoff, "Neither..., Nor..." SMART stories. [[Amazon Publishing]], 111 pages, (2012)<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.amazon.com/dp/B008GNLKUW | title = Vladimir Anisimoff SMART stories '''Neither..., Nor...'''}}</ref>
=== Personal life === Vladimir Anisimoff married (1975) on the cousin of the famous Soviet actress [[Marina Neyolova]] Nina Ivanova (Neyolova at her mother). He has two adult children. Son Dmitry Anisimov<ref>{{citation | url =http://www.anisimovdmitry.com/ | title = phd student Dmitry Anisimov}}</ref> work mathematician in [[University of Lugano|USI]] in the group of well-known scientist Kai Hormann<ref>{{citation | url =http://www.inf.usi.ch/hormann/ | title = Profile of Professor Kai Hormann}}</ref> and live in [[Lugano]], Switzerland.
